SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient has been feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He reports that these symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure regularly. However, his diet has been off due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently.

The patient endorses shortness of breath when exerting energy and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. He also reports a slight cough, which he attributes to a possible cold or change in seasons.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, lightheadedness
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath, chest cramps
• Respiratory: Slight cough
• Gastrointestinal: Bloating

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally
• Lower Extremities: 1+ pitting edema

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest x-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if weight gain or shortness of breath occurs. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any other injuries. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation. No calf pain.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to take every 6 hours with food for 2 weeks.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with some heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning. He heard a pop in his back and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. The pain has been persistent and stiff since then. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, but these did not provide significant relief. He experienced some tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He has been taking his medication for hypertension but reports that his blood pressure readings have been running a little high.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever or chills.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies joint pain or swelling.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

1. Lumbar strain.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
   • Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

2. Diabetes type 2.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has been compliant with medication but admits to poor dietary choices recently. His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has been taking medication, but blood pressure readings have been running high.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has been monitoring his knee and has not reported any significant issues.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current management and monitoring.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. The patient reports doing relatively well, with some stress related to moving his daughter into college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He is still working on controlling his hypertension and admits to occasionally forgetting to take his medication on weekends.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional shortness of breath with exertion, chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: No significant issues.
• Psychiatric: Depression managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac and has not had any incidents recently.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue current management strategies.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has no significant respiratory issues.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled in the office, but he admits to occasional noncompliance with medication on weekends.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication regimen and encourage compliance.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls four days ago. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain management but reports continued pain.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female who presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: Occasional, once or twice a year.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
Respiratory: Normal lung sounds.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Reassess blood work in 8-12 weeks.
2. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
3. Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy. Call clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with worsening headaches over the past few months. He has no prior history of headaches, and his past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Mr. Ward works as a computer programmer and has been married for 25 years. He recently bought a small house. He does not drink alcohol, smoke, or use recreational drugs.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21: Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Monitor the patient's vision and headaches post-surgery for improvement.

The patient is informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery, including infection, need for further surgery, wound issues, seizure, stroke, permanent numbness, weakness, difficulty speaking, or death. The patient understands the risks and agrees to proceed with the surgery.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient experienced chest pain for four days and sought care at the emergency room. She reports that the pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and felt sharp. The pain was worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since the initial episode. She has a history of uterine fibroids and anemia.

The patient had a normal cardiac workup in the emergency room, including EKG and blood tests. The ER providers suspected a GI-related issue and referred her for further evaluation.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports going through a stressful job transition around the time of her symptoms.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of GI problems.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain, weight loss, weight gain, and bowel movement issues.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved, and she has not experienced any recurrence since the initial episode.

PLAN

1. The patient will self-monitor her symptoms and call the office if any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms occur.
2. If the patient experiences a recurrence or worsening of symptoms, she will be scheduled for an EGD to further evaluate her esophagus and stomach.
3. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female, former 34 and 3-week-old twin, with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues and leg problems associated with the syndrome.

The patient's twin sister is doing well and has no health issues.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Reflux.
Feeding difficulties.
Developmental delays.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ripple pea protein milk (non-dairy milk).

RESULTS

Pending kidney ultrasound.

ASSESSMENT

• Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
• Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Perform a kidney ultrasound to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed. If abnormalities are found, schedule a follow-up appointment at the Town Center location.
3. Continue with current therapies (feeding, occupational, physical, and speech).

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow up as needed. Continue with current therapies and specialist appointments. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. She reports that her right wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling and bruising on the right wrist.
Neurological: Reports slight tingling in fingers.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is normal. No lower extremity edema.
NEURO: Normal sensation. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively at first, with a brace for her right wrist. I have also advised her to undergo surgery as soon as possible to ensure proper healing. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times a week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the office if her pain does not improve or worsens, or if she has any concerns or questions.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, currently on 20 mg of Lisinopril.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: not provided
Respiration: not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with a medial collateral ligament strain.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Recommend a knee brace for support and ice therapy (20 minutes, 3-4 times daily) to reduce swelling. Advise patient to elevate and rest the affected leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is elevated at 150/70 mmHg and has a history of hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Refer patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage hypertension.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related to that. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap "giving out" while walking. The pain passes quickly and does not last long. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medications for the pain. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and participating in line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain, prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a Hemoglobin A1c test and lipid panel for diabetes management and to determine if adjustments to Metformin are needed.

The patient has no further questions. The nurse will assist in scheduling the echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She reports a persistent sore throat and a dry cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members and nursing staff.

TREATMENT HISTORY

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports dry cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles in lungs may be due to radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be due to inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during winter, which tend to linger. Patient's family owns a donut shop. Patient denies smoking or living with anyone who smokes.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient denies any family history of immune deficiencies.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain or diarrhea.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neck
- Examination: No lymphadenopathy.

Abdominal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender.

RESULTS

Lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows low IgA levels, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other symptoms that would indicate a more severe immunodeficiency.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. I explained that IgA deficiency is common and most people live their entire lives without knowing they have it. I advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their gastrointestinal tract. If any of these occur, further evaluation may be needed.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check for other immunodeficiencies. The patient was advised to inform any healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that the pain began approximately four days ago and is localized to the inside of his right elbow. The pain is described as a 6/10 in intensity and radiates slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. He has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain has been interfering with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist. No pain with supination.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis and the treatment plan. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during recent outdoor activity.
Genitourinary: No complaints.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: Not reported
Heart Rate: Not reported
Oxygen Saturation: Not reported

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a 45-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. The onset of his pain began several days ago, with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe, making it difficult for him to find a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and his father also had them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

GI: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.
GU: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient will be given a strainer to use when he urinates until the stone passes. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient is advised to contact me if his symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister became unroofed, revealing thick, soft, and mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. He has been on antibiotics for six days, and his temperature was 99.7°F with chills. The ulcer has turned black around the edges, and he experiences cramping in his calf muscle. He also has a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. He has been coughing and experiencing shortness of breath.

He has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400s range for the last two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His A1c is 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every three to four months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: Cramping in calf muscle.
Respiratory: Coughing and shortness of breath.
Skin: Right foot ulcer with black edges, red streak, and heat.
Neurological: Diabetic neuropathy.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: Necrotic wound on the heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and foul odor. No bony exposure.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Pain: No pain upon pressing the affected area of the wound.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Diabetic neuropathy

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the following plan:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on the results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in seven days.
6. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist for diabetes management.

The patient understands the plan and has no further questions or concerns at this time.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever or chills. Reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite.
Musculoskeletal: Denies any new joint pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.

Skin
- Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a bull's-eye rash over the right knee, which is concerning for Lyme disease.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Patient reports blood sugars running in the 120s.

4. Kidney function.
- Medical Treatment: Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function, as patient is concerned about potential metformin-related kidney issues.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
